title: What percentage of votes will the African National Congress win in South Africa's next election for the National Assembly?
preds: Following the end of President Jacob Zuma's term, the ANC party has been plagued by a recession, corruption, and assassinations, which have diminished its reputation among South Africans (https://www.cfr.org/blog/anc-power-broker-arrested-prior-elections-south-africa). The ANC's share of votes in local elections has declined to about 54% since 2016 following these controversies as party supporters either opt out of voting or support opposition parties like the Economic Freedom Fighters; however, there has been no data to suggest that a significant percentage of ANC party supporters have switched their support to these opposition groups (https://worldin2019.economist.com/southafricaselection). Following President Zuma's removal from power, Cyril Ramaphosa has been working to restore the party and the office of the president by criticizing those who supported Zuma. Although Zuma is supported among poor and rural factions who may be resurgent during this election cycle, it is very likely that Ramaphosa will win in South Africa's next election because the majority of black voters will not desert the party associated with Nelson Mandela and the abolition of apartheid (https://www.cfr.org/blog/despite-challenges-south-africas-anc-likely-remain-power). In addition, an Ipsos poll conducted from February to March of this year suggests that the ANC's main opposition parties will receive no more than 16% for the Democratic Alliance and 9% for the Economic Freedom Fighters parties (https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/sa-voter-turnout-will-be-critical-in-elections2019-ipsos-poll-19968042).

As of May 2019, the polls indicate that the ANC will take 50.3% of the votes (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/859796). I do not see this wavering as the elections are happening tomorrow and no more scandals have come into play (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/07/world/africa/south-africa-elections-anc-ramaphosa.html), and there is a good chance that the ANC will stay the same if not increase their hold on the election.
They seem to be hovering around 50% with most poll results a little above that number.

There is hope that Ramaphosa will be able to institute change, but optimism is fairly low, and evidence of corruption in the ANC could be/is reducing appreciation for the party. Unemployment rose after the ANC’s rise to power in 1994, (and continues to rise) and the coincidence of high public sounding and low growth provides an unfavorable economic situation. There is discontent over land reform and property rights, the school system, and corruption. There isn’t indication of real plans to alter policies which could combat the issues within the administration and the ANC, which could damage public opinion. That said, the ANC has a lot of power, and has won in the past – opinion polls show support at 56.4%, which is lower than the 2014 elections but still significant. Incumbent advantage, success with institution of basic services, hope for Ramaphosa, division within the opposing party (DA), and historical role all give clout to the ANC. This makes it most likely that they will win between 50-60% of the votes, least likely that they will win less than 50%, and somewhat possible that they win over 60%.  https://www.economist.com/leaders/2019/04/25/to-stop-the-rot-in-south-africa-back-cyril-ramaphosa
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-48151036
https://www.washingtonpost.com
https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2019/may/05/the-guardian-view-on-south-africas-elections-ramaphosa-needs-a-mandate
New Ipsos poll has ANC at 61%: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-04-29/poll-shows-south-africa-s-anc-winning-61-support-in-may-8-vote

This one is really hard. It appears loads of people that are abroad are voting DA, and that people are aware of past and possible current corruption of ANC, but I'm not sure that they will trust a different party will be able to overcome corruption. I am going to go for guessing that deciding percentage of people who feel there is no hop will not vote but people supporting DA will vote. https://af.reuters.com/article/idAFKCN1QX067-OZATP
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-04-29/the-man-who-would-remake-south-africa
https://www.thesouthafrican.com/elections-2019-latest-voter-poll-april-2019/

For the past 25 years, the ANC has been the governing national party of South Africa. Despite the corruption and scandal that encompassed much of the previous half decade of South Africa due to President Zuma. The nominee for the ANC this year Cyril Ramaphosa, is running on a platform to root out and clean up much of Zuma's corruption and poor policy that had plundered South Africa's economy and caused such a promising state to collapse. Under Ramaphosa many in South Africa are hopeful he can be the one to enact change and clean up South Africa and give life back to its economy. The only real challenge to the ANC and Ramaphosa is the Democratic Alliance or (DA) who are led by nominee Mmusi Maimane. Although the DA is far less corrupt and a change of party could help South Africa, their political power in the country stops at the Provincial level as the national voting population of South Africa has historically in large numbers voted for the ANC. For these reasons it is likely that the ANC will win 50-60% of the votes and depending on the impact of the DA could be over 60% or less than 50%.  https://www.economist.com/leaders/2019/04/25/to-stop-the-rot-in-south-africa-back-cyril-ramaphosa
Tough call. I bet on inertia and genuine desire to clean up the ANC.  https://www.economist.com/leaders/2019/04/25/to-stop-the-rot-in-south-africa-back-cyril-ramaphosa

It is weighing up Ramaphosa (hope vote vs reality vs loyalty) vs inroads made by the EFF pulling votes away from the ANC, the unknown though is if they gain that extra ground from newly registered voters (more likely due to appeal to youthful ignorance) or taking away from previous ANC voters.

For 25 years, the ANC has held on to power, most recent polls have estimated that 52% of South African voters would vote for the ANC if the election was today (https://www.thesouthafrican.com/elections-2019-irr-voter-survey-surge-eff-support/). However, other major parties such as the DA have claimed that current polling numbers have been flawed due to being outdated and "methodologically flawed" (https://www.thesouthafrican.com/the-only-poll-that-matters-is-the-election-da/). Additionally, other parties have grown in strength, such as the EFF, meaning that the ANC's grip is slowly eroding. In fact, Zuma's presidential leadership probably hastened that effect (https://www.cfr.org/blog/despite-challenges-south-africas-anc-likely-remain-power). That being said, I feel that the ANC will still maintain widespread support, and a watershed moment would be needed in order to reliably drop them below 50%, something I really don't believe has happened.
I am an American working abroad. My South African friends tell me they will get the vote despite massive corruption.
Previous election the ANC achieved 64% support but voter support for ANC has continued to shrink.  I would also predict a lower turnout in this election compared to the previous election.

Primarily on the basis of opinion polls and by-elections, but also on recent bad news for the ANC - Alexandra protests, Zondo Commission revelations - could lead to lower turnout of previous ANC supporters.
Anything less then 50% would be something of a political earthquake.
Another report pointing toward a worse outcome for ANC: https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/politics/2019-04-11-by-election-results-point-to-trouble-for-anc/
Long lasting regimes in poor countries tend to remain until external parties come
ANC is the dominant political party in South Africa and I am not aware of anything that is changing
Black South Africans see them as the liberators of the masses. Corruption on a large scale doesn’t matter.
The trend away from the ANC is likely to continue, even though the number of scandals seems to be a bit lower these days.
Because there is dissatisfaction with the anc and corruption in South Africa but it is still the party of Mandela
The DA are a much more inclusive party and people are more aware of the long running corruption that existed in the ANC
New poll shifts my probabilities a bit: https://www.thesouthafrican.com/2019-election-south-africa-latest-opinion-polls-afrobarometer/

The ANC has lost support due to the Eskom fiasco. In addition, there are massive numbers of unemployed young South Africans who are disaffected with the ANC and who want a more revolutionary approach - many of these people will support the EFF.

Seeing as support was 62% in 2014 and 54% in 2016, it seems unlikely that the ANC will get over 60% of the vote. While a poll by Ipsos shows a 61% support by registered voters, another by the South African Institute of Race Relations polls the ANC at about 55%, similar to their support in 2016. Although Ramaphosa has publicly championed cleaning up the corruption and sour taste left behind by Zuma, the economy is not doing well and the average citizen feels that more than cleaning up corruption.
The economy is in poor shape but politics is tribal
Peter Mokaba will take some votes away from the ANC. The DA is weekened and won't gain much ground so the majority will still stay with the ANC despite it being a divided house
Little knowledge on this but ANC have been falling in support due to domestic issues, weak currency - supports Upvote, no real opposition - weak upvote
ANC power is declining - too centrist to capture radical vote and too radical for centrist vote.

Base rate: Since 1994, the vote share of the ANC has always (100%) been more than 60% [1]. Rule of three would probably be misleading due to small sample size. [2] Polls [3]: Since the last election, 2 out of 9 (22%) had them below 50%, 22% had them above 60% and 56% had them between. Most recent poll has the ANC at 61%. Taking into account all 2019 polls, weighted by sample size, we get 58.8%. These should take into account corruption and scandals, at least better than I could by myself.  2014 Feb/Mar polling by Ipsos predicted the end result fairly well. [3] If anything, polls seemed to have underestimated the end result. Given the strong base rate and no recent poll even close to below 50%, I estimate the probability at 3%. Currently, the end result seems very close to 60%, so probability mass seems roughly equal between the other two options. Base rate and most recent polling seem to be better predictors to me than previous polling or "inside view" arguments. Polls seemed to have underestimated. That pushes mass toward "more than 60%". How much? Let's go with 8 percentage points for now. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Assembly_of_South_Africa#History
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_of_three_(statistics)
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_South_African_general_election#Opinion_polling
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_South_African_general_election#Opinion_polling

For the entire history of South African elections, the ANC has held 62-69% of the South African National Assembly. Though this question was created in the face large corruption charges against higher-ups in the party including the former President. However, the ANC has had a number of controversies from restricting the freedom of the press to the failure to protect miners from a massacre during a strike. The ANC still has a lot of influence in the country and Zuma is no longer the frontrunner of the party. Therefore, the percentage of votes the African National Congress will win will stay within the 60%s

Most likely outcome is a repeat of the 2016 LGE Results.  Despite a decline for the ANC over the years, South Africans are slow to change their votes.  Ramaphosa's popularity will likely be enough to arrest further declines, while probably not enough to boost the ANC's vote share much beyond 55%.  There is also the trend that the ruling party seems to be much better at getting its voters out during National elections than during LGE, so I see a minor chance for the party to scrape past the 60% mark, but not by much.
Starting with polling results from here: ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_South_African_general_election ).  The last IPSOS poll had 61% for ANC, and the last IRR poll had 54.7% for ANC.

Current polls put the ANC at 61% right between two buckets.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_South_African_general_election

As per polls and recent elections. 1. Polls show 61% support
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_South_African_general_election 2. ANC has won every election since 1994.
3. ANC won last election with 62% support. Less than 50% support would go against electoral results of the last 24 years. More than 60 is improbable because of ANC corruption. The middle bucket is the likeliest statistically.

The ANC's vote share has dropped a few points in each of the last elections, in part because of one off factors like the unpopularity of Jacob Zuma but also because of longer term trends like the emergence of the EFF to its left. in the 2016 municipal elections they dropped to 55% of the vote. While the new president is more popular than Zuma, I expect the ANC to hover around that number or maybe fall a bit below it.

The Ipsos poll indicated that the ANC could secure 61% of national votes, the DA 18% and the EFF 10% in the May elections. The main points of the Ipsos poll are: https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/anc-could-win-60-of-votes-in-may-8-election-new-poll-suggests-20190319
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_South_African_general_election

Some assessments in 2009 suggested that this was the last election the ANC would be able to win outright due to increased income inequality, infrastructure failures, flat economic outlook and a the growing expectations of the middle class. Despite load shedding and water difficulties compounding the ANC's electoral chances I think the assessment correct and the ANC will still have a small majority of the total vote but for the last time.

https://www.economist.com/leaders/2019/02/16/how-south-africa-should-tackle-corruption

This is a tough one and I think that the current crowd forecast is way over confident. 1) Base rate is 100% "More than 60%" because the ANC has never gotten less than 60% of the vote in any election since 1994. [1] However, their support peaked in 2004 and has declined by about 4% each election.
Year	ANC
1994	62.65
1999	66.35
2004	69.69
2009	65.9
2014	62.15 2) The polling data analysis done by @sreichau is spot on. I went back a little further in the polls which put my numbers at 8.55%,  69.80%, and  21.60% for the <50%, 50-60%, and >60% brackets, respectively. [2] 3) The DA party has gained about 4.5% of the vote in each election since 1999. [3] 
Year	DA
1994	1.73
1999	9.65
2004	12.37
2009	16.66
2014	22.23 If the trends of ANC decline and DA ascendancy continue, this could be the first election since its founding that the ANC gets less than 60% of the vote. However, much like many other nations, SA has a big voter apathy problem and the number of registered voters didn't seem to change much since the last election, [4] meaning that support for the DA (or any other opposition party) would have to come from ANC defectors. This puts me squarely at 50/50 for the 50-60% and >60% brackets. Since 50/50 is the same probability of flipping a coin (and I would like to think that I can do better than that, maybe?), I'm starting with 0%, 63%, and 37%.  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_South_Africa#List_of_elections
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_South_African_general_election#Opinion_polling
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_South_Africa#List_of_elections
[4] https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/opinionista/2019-01-21-apathy-is-a-silent-majority-when-43-of-south-africans-refuse-to-vote/

Power cuts because of corruption and lack of investment under Zuma and his friends are a very strong message, and the ANC are rightly worried. They may not lose out to any individual party but the risk of losing the unchallengeable mandate they once had is very high.

Taking polling data with end of field period Dec 2018 or later from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_South_African_general_election, averaging ANC percentages gives 58% as the mean. Assuming a normal distribution with standard deviation 1.7 gives 0,88,12. Placing a slight hedge on the lowest bucket.
